commentBody:
TIL MOOT has two definitions that are completely opposite of each other:

adjective
1.
subject to debate, dispute, or uncertainty.
"whether they had been successful or not was a moot point"

2.
having little or no practical relevance, typically because the subject is too uncertain to allow a decision.
"the whole matter is becoming increasingly moot"

The example sentence from 1 would be completely incomprehensible without additional context

Warsaw's Tomb of the Unknown Soldier (Gr√≥b Nieznanego ≈ªo≈Çnierza) is located in Marshal J√≥zef Pi≈Çsudski square. It was created in the 1920s under the central arcade of Pa≈Çac Saski (The Saxon Palace, so named for Poland's 18th century Saxon dynasty), Warsaw's biggest, grandest historical building. The palace was completely destroyed in WW2. The Tomb survived though, and it's still there, with a ruined portion of the arcade over it. Recently work has begun on the reconstruction of the palace - as a pet project of the 2015-2023 autocratic government, it has rightly proved highly controversial and had been challenged in the courts. The thing is, Warsaw was virtually annihilated during the war, and while some of the iconic buildings and streets were reconstructed in the 1940s-1970s, we're OK with the rest being gone forever - we made peace with it and moved on, creating new spaces, looking forward rather than back. Bombastic projects don't sit well with many of us.

for a weekend and brings every single article

spring break, and

 during this time.

at home every August.

the accumulated stuff.

With a door.
For the smell.

put a sign in the yard,

Yes indeedy, "MOOT" is a contranym, or sorta: it can either mean "debatable" (the meaning that twee prescriptivists insist is the only correct one), or "not worthy of debate," which is the one that is more common for us North American dopes.

The latter comes from a practice of law students of having "moot courts"--i.e. practice courts, in which the students would debate cases, the outcomes of which would have no legal or practical force. Also, the second meaning of "moot" dates back to at least 1830, so if we're dopes, we've been dopes for quite some time.

Anyhoo, both these meanings come from an archaic noun "moot", which meant "meeting, assembly" (comparable to an archaic use of "thing," to mean much the same; or to "diet"--wouldn't it be great if called it the "Diet of Davos" [although there was only one worm in attendance.])  Tolkien lovers will recognize this in his coinage of "Entmoot."

But here's my fun discovery for the day! The OED list another, probably unrelated, dialectical meaning of "moot," for a "stump of a tree." Now, Tolkien really couldn't do humor at all, but he was good at coming up with clever twists on language, and I wouldn't be surprised if he had this second meaning in mind as well when he coined with "entmoot."

***

@Steven M.

@Steven M.

@Heidi

@Al  in Pittsburgh

@Patricia Henry
Anyone who has participated in a law school 'moot court' will argue that it means 'arguable'. You may take that point as settled -- i.e., not moot.

@Steven M.
Definition 2 (now try not to get too upset here) is wrong. Something becomes moot because a change of circumstances means it is no longer relevant. It has nothing to do with uncertainty. Something may be perfectly certain and still become moot. 
Sense 1: Will the US have a civil war? There are arguments on both sides; it's a moot point.
Sense 2: Did the Civil War transform the US transportation grid? What's done is done. Except to historians, it's a moot point.

@Patrick J.
I've never heard it used in the UK myself. It was quite a common word on Law and Order on TV, and I had to look it up in a dictionary.
@Jane Wheelaghan I have actually, albeit not often.

I struggled with this clue because I've only heard "moot" in (kind of) the second sense. To me it refers to something that's irrelevant because some external factor has taken care of it or removed its significance. There's no debate or uncertainty, it's just not important any more.
Arguing about whether to pack the factor 30 or factor 50 sunscreen for a day at the beach, but then you find the car won't start so you won't go to the beach at all. The sunscreen debate is is now moot, any reasons given during it are now moot points because the whole thing isn't happening anyway.
And then you remember you live in Scotland so it was all just a dream, grab the umbrellas and wellies and go for a nice walk in the rain.

@Steven M.
As I read this lengthy thread, I am reminded of Joey‚Äôs statement that a comment made by another ‚ÄúFriends‚Äù cast member was a ‚Äúmoo‚Äù point. When questioned, he explained  that it was not worth discussing, like a cow‚Äôs opinion.

Heidi,

@Steven M. Evan Edinger had a video recently about words and phrases that mean the opposite thing in the US and the UK. He covers table and moot. It's quite interesting! (I'm using quite as an American here.) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4fQGz6CHP4w

The internet is wrong. (I am engulfed by surprise...) 
The Hebrew (Genesis 8:4) has the ark settling on 'harei Ararat.' /Har/ means mountain (sing. nom.) but Hebrew inflects its nouns. This phrase would ordinarily be read as 'the mountains of Ararat'.
But our problem is that the ark is one vessel; it can only be in one place at a time. Solutions might include:  the ark poised between two mountains; the ark settled on one, then further settling on another; reading preposition 'on' as meaning 'amid'; reading 'harei' not as an ordinary appositive plural -- the mountains of,  but as an irregular appositive singular -- the mountain of.
Pick your interpretation. I'm sure there are others.

@B He/they is perfectly cromulent -- as a pronoun pair, it indicates that the person is okay with either masculine or gender-neutral pronouns.

@B As Leontion says, the convention is that multi-pronoun sets just list the subject pronouns, because it's less unwieldy than the full list and because most people know how to conjugate the standard pronouns (he, she, they). While the standard for single-pronoun usage is subject/object (like he/him), which is especially necessary with neopronouns (like xe/xem), multi-pronoun usage is just subject. So "he/they" doesn't mean you should say "He is over there, give it to they", but rather some combination of "he is"/"they are" and "to him"/"to them".

@Matt

What you're doing would be considered an exploit, also known as clever used of in-game mechanics, in a video game. As an abuser of gaming exploits myself, I respect you for it and I'll play along.

I'm a very visual person and so I sometimes find experimental visual art interesting. Not beautiful, mind you - and ultimately I need my art to be beautiful, on some level - but occasionally thought-provoking, or simply innovative to the point of that being of value in itself. That being said, I much prefer modern sculpture to modern painting. The presence of a sculpture in a 3d space, the tangible form proof of the sheer effort of creating it, often move me, while a flat canvas full of blots and smears leaves me cold more often than not.

To some extent this applies to adult entertainment, too.
